clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Food Combination on Starch Digestion and Gastric Processing
clinical_study.official_title: Digestion: Building a Better Health and Better Understanding the Digestive Processes Thanks to Magnetic Resonance Imaging

lead_sponsor.agency: Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique

collaborator.agency: IR4M (Imagerie par Résonance Magnétique Médicale et Multi-Modalités)

clinical_study.source: Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique

brief_summary.textblock: The results of our in vitro studies strengthen the hypothesis that the contribution of salivary alpha-amylase to starch digestion has been underrated and that this enzyme can play an important role in this process. As a result, its inhibition could constitute an opportunity to reduce the glycemic response elicited by starch-rich foods. The main goal of this study is to verify whether inhibition of salivary alpha-amylase, upon the consumption of starchy foods, can have an impact on the postprandial glycemic response, and/or satiety.

detailed_description.textblock:
This single-blind, randomized, crossover study will be divided into two parts. Part 1 comprises a total of 3 test-meals for which postprandial glycemia, subjective appetite levels and consumption in the following meal (ad libitum meal) will be evaluated.
Part 2 is to be carried out with another group of 10 participants and the same test meals as in Part 1. Digestion of these meals will be monitored in real-time with Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). Postprandial glycemia and subjective appetite scores, will be measured in parallel to enable the comparison with the results of Part 1.

primary_outcome.description: Consumption at an ad libitum meal served 3 h after each test-meal during part 1
Gastric empting kinetics of each test-meal, evaluated by MRI, during part 2

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline and and at different time-points during 3 hours after after consuming the test meal (Part 1 and 2)
At baseline and at different time-points during 3 hours after consuming the test meal (Part 1 and 2) and immediately after the ad libitum meal (Part 1 only)
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluation of satiety, fullness, hunger, prospective food consumption and desire to eat through visual analogue scales (VAS)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline and during 3 hours after after consuming the test meal (Part 2 only)
secondary_outcome.description: Analysis of MRI scans will be carried out to evaluate the frequency of gastric contractions.
The amylolytic activity of saliva samples collected before the test meal will be determined.

secondary_outcome.measure: Saliva incorporation in the food bolus
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the end of the test-meal (t=15 min) (Part 1)
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of saliva incorporated in a food bolus during oral processing will be determined once per participant for each test meal

other_outcome.time_frame: 12-16 hours after the test meal (Part 1 and 2)
other_outcome.description: Digital questionnaire that will be answered at the end of the day in order to provide a reference point regarding the potential effects of the test-meal throughout the rest of the day (ex. appetite, food consumption, discomfort sensations)

arm_group.description: Participants in this arm will randomly consume bread and 250 mL of water on 1 out of 3 visits of Part 1.
Participants in this arm will randomly consume bread and 250 mL of lemon juice on 1 out of 3 visits of Part 1.
Participants in this arm will randomly consume bread and 250 mL of tea on 1 out of 3 visits of Part 1.
Participants in this arm will randomly consume bread and 250 mL of water supplemented with 20 peas on 1 out of 3 visits of Part 2.
Participants in this arm will randomly consume bread and 250 mL of lemon juice supplemented with 20 peas on 1 out of 3 visits of Part 2.
Participants in this arm will randomly consume bread and 250 mL of tea supplemented with 20 peas on 1 out of 3 visits of Part 2.

intervention.description: Serving of wheat bread providing 50 g of carbohydrates

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- To be overall healthy
- To be between 18 and 60 years old
- BMI between 18 and 25 (lean)
- No eating disorders
- No major weight changes (> 3kg in previous 3 months)
- Structured eating habits (3 main meals/day, everyday)
- Not using corticoid drugs, or antidepressives known to influence food consumption, appetite and/or mood.
- Not using medication known to influence glucose tolerance: acetylsalicylic acid or thyroxin, vitamin or mineral-based dietary supplements, and drugs to control hypertension or osteoporosis are acceptable
- No allergies to the foods in the test-meals and ad libitum meal
- No abusive alcohol consumption
- No intensive exercising habits
- No participation in a clinical study within the previous 6 months
- To enjoy the foods in the test-meals and ad libitum meals
- To be affiliated to a social security system
- To be available to participate in study sessions
- To have read and signed the Informed consent form
Additional criteria for Part 2
- Ability to be in an MRI scan without moving
- Ability to hold breath for 25s (a requirement for certain MRI exams)
Non-inclusion criteria:
- History of diabetes, use of antihyperglycemic drugs or insulin to treat diabetes or associated conditions
- Major medical interventions or surgeries requiring hospitalization within the previous 3 months
- Any medical condition that affects digestion and/or nutrient absorption
- Use of steroids, protease inhibitors and/or antipsychotic drugs
- Use of anticoagulation drugs
- To be participating in another clinical trial, or to be within the exclusion period of a previous clinical trial
- Having started or stopped smoking within the previous 3 months
Additional exclusion criteria for Part 2:
- Any contraindications to an MRI exam: claustrophobia, tatoos, presence of ferromagnetic elements, having a pacemaker, metallic prosthesis, cochlear implants, vascular clips, insulin pumps
- Any condition or disease that might affect the results of MRI exams.
